labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Fix wording about lowercase labels
issues.author: JonathanLennox
issues.body:
The text
> Each of the preceding labels are identified using the lowercase form of the label in [TLS13], except as noted.

was confusing to me, because the labels were clearly in uppercase, until I figured out that it was saying that the labels are in lowercase in TLS13 but in uppercase in SSLKEYLOGFILE.  I'm not sure the best way to fix the wording, but it could be clearer.

issues.title: Add an example?
issues.author: JonathanLennox
issues.body: Having example SSLKEYLOGFILE content (for both TLS13 and TLS12) might be helpful.

issues.title: Many transactions in a file
issues.author: paulehoffman
issues.body:
The draft says "Implementations that record secrets to a file do so continuously as those secrets are generated." However, the examples are only for a single secret per file, and there is no indication of how a file that has multiple secrets differentiates betwen the secrets. Parsing a file for multiple secrets is made more difficult for TLS 1.3 because the labels for a secret are a set, not a list.

Proposal: add some text about adding a comment between each secret, and expand the examples to show multiple secrets in the file.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
I'm not sure about the commenting.  I know that some libraries do generate comments, but I don't see any interoperability benefit to doing so.

I can add another connection to the example.  That should be easy.

comments.author: paulehoffman
comments.body: Without a comment separators, there is no way for a log parser to tell when a new connection starts unless each connection has all the labels. Maybe this isn't important, but I can imagine a dumb parser getting some connections wrong.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Ah, there is no "start" or "end" involved.  The log can include secrets that are interleaved from multiple connections.

This is the output of some of our test code, showing multiple connections, each made in sequence (open, connect, close, open, connect, close).  Note that both client and server a logging into the same file, so the same connection appears twice:

<details>
<summary>Sequential log</summary>

```
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a 59ec0981b211a743f22d5a46a1fc77a2b230e16ef0de6d4e418abfe90eff10bf
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a a37fe4d3b6c9a6a372396b1562f6f8a40c1c3f85f1aa9b02d5ed46c4a1301365
CLIENT_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a e9160bca1a531d871f5ecf51943d8cfb88833adeccf97701546b5fb93e030d79
SERVER_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a fb1120b91e48d402fac20faa33880e77bace82c85d6688df0aa99bf5084430e4
EXPORTER_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a db1f4fa1a6942fb125d4cc47e02938b6f8030c6956bb81b9e3269f1cf855a8f8
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a 59ec0981b211a743f22d5a46a1fc77a2b230e16ef0de6d4e418abfe90eff10bf
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a a37fe4d3b6c9a6a372396b1562f6f8a40c1c3f85f1aa9b02d5ed46c4a1301365
CLIENT_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a e9160bca1a531d871f5ecf51943d8cfb88833adeccf97701546b5fb93e030d79
SERVER_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a fb1120b91e48d402fac20faa33880e77bace82c85d6688df0aa99bf5084430e4
EXPORTER_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a db1f4fa1a6942fb125d4cc47e02938b6f8030c6956bb81b9e3269f1cf855a8f8
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 52b4fc06776e40a9e346813cc7478d3b59ce5d011339508c10ec90b7208edcc7
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 ca5c1d6451233668d17fd777dbd2fab94f9ef9007d50beda5cbc4e09cde6d7c6
CLIENT_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 c6d9818178e39d6637c983b557118b20895fca8b68973361fedd47fd4743467d
SERVER_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 8621a980843415bdad95e5cd9371e43d204434b5506b0a4de44cb62a735e22fd
EXPORTER_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 11b9c305d1f88f1d80534aa7a76b5fb3f31c5b7c125e3df7b8ba46604e3af8ce
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 52b4fc06776e40a9e346813cc7478d3b59ce5d011339508c10ec90b7208edcc7
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 ca5c1d6451233668d17fd777dbd2fab94f9ef9007d50beda5cbc4e09cde6d7c6
CLIENT_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 c6d9818178e39d6637c983b557118b20895fca8b68973361fedd47fd4743467d
SERVER_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 8621a980843415bdad95e5cd9371e43d204434b5506b0a4de44cb62a735e22fd
EXPORTER_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 11b9c305d1f88f1d80534aa7a76b5fb3f31c5b7c125e3df7b8ba46604e3af8ce
```
</details>

As you can see, the ClientHello.random field (the second one) just repeats.

But a real server will often look more like this:

<details>
<summary>Interleaved log</summary>

```
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a 59ec0981b211a743f22d5a46a1fc77a2b230e16ef0de6d4e418abfe90eff10bf
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a a37fe4d3b6c9a6a372396b1562f6f8a40c1c3f85f1aa9b02d5ed46c4a1301365
CLIENT_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 52b4fc06776e40a9e346813cc7478d3b59ce5d011339508c10ec90b7208edcc7
SERVER_HANDSHAKE_TRAFFIC_SECRET 635fc8c76eb35690a3d9ba7647501ddf812944f9529fd74489476b9cae101786 ca5c1d6451233668d17fd777dbd2fab94f9ef9007d50beda5cbc4e09cde6d7c6
CLIENT_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a e9160bca1a531d871f5ecf51943d8cfb88833adeccf97701546b5fb93e030d79
SERVER_TRAFFIC_SECRET_0 b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a fb1120b91e48d402fac20faa33880e77bace82c85d6688df0aa99bf5084430e4
EXPORTER_SECRET b2eb93b8ddab8c228993567947bca1e133736980c22754687874e3896f7d6d0a db1f4fa1a6942fb125d4cc47e02938b6f8030c6956bb81b9e3269f1cf855a8f8
```
</details>

The thing here is that the keys arrive at different times, so they are logged at different times.

Yes, this is a problem for tools like Wireshark, but they manage this pretty well.

comments.author: paulehoffman
comments.body: OK, that seems reasonable (but ugly for parsers). I'll close.

pulls.title: Add stronger prohibitions
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
For both old TLS versions and the use of this outside of testing and debugging.

As inspired by @emanjon.

pulls.title: Fix wording
pulls.author: JonathanLennox
pulls.body: The current wording implies that DTLS and QUIC do not use the TLS key schedule.

pulls.title: Minor suggestions
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body: Minor suggestions. Use them as you wish. No need to sync with me.

comments.author: dennisjackson
comments.body:
In the final paragraph of the security considerations, it might be worth clarifying: 

> This draft does not support the export of the resumption_master_secret in TLS1.3 (see {{Section 7.1 of ?RFC8446}}) as exposing this value would impact both the confidentiality and authenticity of data exchanged in future TLS sessions.

```suggestion
and 2.4 of ?RFC4492}}) do not hold if keys are saved.  Logged keys
```

```suggestion
Forward secrecy guarantees provided in TLS 1.3 (see {{Section 1.2 and Appendix
E.1 of ?RFC8446}}) and some modes of TLS 1.2 (such as those in {{Sections 2.2
and 2.4 of ?RFC4492}}) do not hold if key material is recorded.  Access to logged material allows an attacker to decrypt data exchanged in previous TLS connections and so undermine the intended security properties of ?RFC8446. 
```

Not sure what the second sentence was going for so word smithed a bit.

```suggestion
Forward secrecy guarantees provided in TLS 1.3 (see {{Section 1.2 and Appendix
E.1 of ?RFC8446}}) and some modes of TLS 1.2 (such as those in {{Sections 2.2
and 2.4 of ?RFC4492}}) do not hold if key material is recorded.  Access to key
material allows an attacker to decrypt data exchanged in any logged TLS
connections.
```

?

The aspect that I'm trying to bring out is that we're worried about an attacker getting a key log file in the present and then decrypting previously exchanged data they'd recorded (which is the thing that PFS stops). Your proposed second sentence gets rid of the nuance w.r.t. timing. Perhaps insert 'previously' before logged?

I have visions of these keylog files slowly filling up disks, not unlike nuclear waste, insofar as they remain hazardous indefinitely unless properly disposed of. I don't want to take up another round trip, so happy with whatever formulation you like best.

```suggestion
material allows an attacker to decrypt data exchanged in any previously logged TLS
```

pulls.title: Add multiple connections to the example
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
And note that interleaving might happen.

Closes #9.

pulls.title: Update media template
pulls.author: martinthomson

Thanks to Martin Dürst.
